channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Voters Endorse Italian Prime Minister
item.description: Matteo Renzi had the best showing of any European governing party in parliamentary voting, reaching a level no party has seen in an Italian election since 1958.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Tiananmen Comment Eyed After Professor’s Microblog Vanishes
item.description: The popular microblog of a professor at Peking University has been blocked, perhaps because he posted a comment about the military suppression of the 1989 Tiananmen protest movement.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Brazil Is Tired of Being Scolded
item.description: There is a growing feeling that FIFA and the Olympic committee are taking the parent act a bit too far.
item.dc:creator: By VANESSA BARBARA

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Developer’s Fake Sphinx Has Egypt Seething
item.description: A copy of the Great Sphinx of Giza in a Hebei Province cultural park has prompted official protests from the Egyptian antiquities minister.
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: Not what you might think: A man posing on a full-scale replica of the Great Sphinx of Giza in Hebei Province.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Aiding Turkey’s Gay Inmates
item.description: Ankara’s proposal to segregate gay, lesbian and transgender prisoners will do more harm than good.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DIBA NIGAR GOKSEL

item.title: Pistorius Arrives for Psychiatric Assessment
item.description: The outcome of mental health tests ordered by the judge at Oscar Pistorius’s murder trial could influence the course and outcome of the hearings.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Pope Lays Wreath at Tomb of Zionism’s Founder
item.description: The gesture of support to Israel followed several symbolic signals the day before that lent a spiritual lift to Palestinian aspirations for sovereignty.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Pope Francis prayed after laying a wreath at the Yad Vashem Holocaust Memorial.

item.title: Disruption of Ukraine Vote Justifies More Russia Sanctions, U.S. Senator Says
item.description: Senator Kelly Ayotte, a Republican who is critical of President Obama’s response in the region, called for a tougher stance after Sunday’s presidential election.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and SABRINA TAVERNISE

item.title: Thai General Says Coup Has King’s Backing
item.description: Gen. Prayuth Chan-ocha, who overthrew the government Thursday, said Monday that the military would create a “genuine democracy” but gave no time frame for doing so.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: President of E.C.B. Warns of Euro Zone Deflation
item.description: Mario Draghi’s unusually direct comments on the dangers of falling prices raised expectations that the European Central Bank would introduce further stimulus measures.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Beijing Seems to Be Warming Toward Aung San Suu Kyi
item.description: There are new signs that a long-awaited visit to Beijing by Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Myanmar opposition leader, may be getting closer.
item.dc:creator: By WAI MOE
item.media:description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi at a memorial for the writer and political activist U Win Tin in Yangon, Myanmar, on April 23.

item.title: Mass Planned on Mount Zion Stirs Ancient Rivalries
item.description: Opposition has grown in ultra-Orthodox and nationalist religious Jewish circles to a deal between Israel and the Vatican on increased Christian prayer times at the Cenacle.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Tourists visited the Cenacle, venerated by Christians as the room of the Last Supper, earlier this month.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Dog Reported Beaten to Death in Front of Owner in Beijing
item.description: Beijing will probably see a harsher-than-usual drive against unregistered pet dogs this year because of rising rabies infections, vets are warning.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: The dog was a stray that had been adopted by a Briton working at an international school.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Blogger Says He Was Fired After Meeting With Kerry
item.description: Zhang Jialong says Tencent, a Chinese Internet giant, objected to his comments on censorship and his request that the United States pay attention to the cases of prominent dissidents.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The United States secretary of state, John Kerry, at a news conference in Beijing in February.

item.title: India Ink: Global Digital News Brands See Growth Opportunity in India
item.description: BuzzFeed, Huffington Post and Atlantic Media are among the companies with plans to build major online news operations in India, both on their own and with local partners.
item.dc:creator: By MAX BEARAK
item.media:description: A newspaper distributor in New Delhi sorted papers with news of the May election victory of Narendra Modi’s Bharatiya Janata Party.

item.title: Peace-Talk Critic Takes Lead in Colombia Presidential Vote
item.description: Óscar Iván Zuluaga failed to earn the majority needed to be declared the winner and will face President Juan Manuel Santos in a June runoff.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: Voters in Bogota, Colombia looked for their name outside a polling station during the presidential elections on Sunday.

item.title: In Egyptian Town, Cheers for Sisi but Murmurs of Discontent
item.description: In Banha, north of Cairo, the presidential campaign banners for Abdel Fattah el-Sisi are everywhere but some have been defaced, illustrating both the certainty of his election and the challenges he will face.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Boxes of presidential election ballots at a Cairo courthouse on Sunday.

item.title: In Russia, Tune Changes About Leader in Ukraine
item.description: As Petro O. Poroshenko emerged as the front-runner, attitudes toward the billionaire businessman began to shift and personal attacks ceased.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Petro O. Poroshenko at a polling station in Kiev. The billionaire businessman was elected president of Ukraine on Sunday.

item.title: In East, Separatists and Fear Stop Voters
item.description: Just 2 percent of registered voters in Donetsk are said to cast ballot, and Western observers said the election would be legal, even without turnout from the eastern provinces.
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE and ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: An anti-elections demonstration held in the eastern province of Donetsk, an area where pro-Russian separatists have vowed to do everything to prevent voting.

item.title: Damascus Journal: Once Bustling, Syria’s Fractured Railroad Is a Testament to Shattered Ambitions
item.description: The shutdown of the Hejaz railway station in Damascus reflects the lost links of business and society that once connected the region.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Hejaz railway station in Damascus has become a museum popular with history buffs.

item.title: Lebanon Arrests Radical Cleric Who Backed Militants
item.description: Omar Bakri Muhammad, a Syrian-born cleric who preached for years in London, had expressed support for the extremist group Islamic State of Iraq and Syria.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Omar Bakri Muhammad, a Syrian-born cleric who preached for years in London, had expressed support for the extremist group Islamic State of Iraq and Syria.

item.title: Press Battle in Pakistan Feeds Into Larger Conflict: Government vs. Military
item.description: A spat over the shooting of a talk show host, followed by the government’s reversal of a ban on the station, has exposed tensions between Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif and top officials.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Employees of Geo News at a rally in Karachi, Pakistan. A news media spat over the shooting of a Geo talk show host has widened.

item.title: Fringe Groups Gain in European Voting
item.description: Preliminary reports from several countries, including the Czech Republic, Slovakia and Malta, suggested that voter interest had decreased compared with previous elections.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: A election official waited for voters to cast their ballots on Sunday in Massama, Portugal.

item.title: Obama Makes Surprise Trip to Afghanistan
item.description: The president did not meet with the departing Afghan leader, Hamid Karzai, instead focusing on talking to American service members about the coming withdrawal.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG and MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: President Obama spoke to troops during a surprise visit to Bagram Airfield in Afghanistan.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Back From Beyond: The D.S.K. Show
item.description: That some today see him as a potential savior, despite his many failings, says a lot about French politics.
item.dc:creator: By SYLVIE KAUFFMANN
